reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s key optimistic pathway: partial AM-convergence plus moral trade/compromise (and the idea that threats are a manageable downside). If the critique landed, it would substantially weaken the paper’s main source of optimism, though not the entire essay (which also argues against WAM-convergence and discusses many blockers), hence moderately high centrality. However, much of the critique is already acknowledged in the position: section 3.3 explicitly flags threats as potentially value-destroying (even worse than extinction), questions whether stable mutually agreeable legal regimes exist, and notes that threats/extortion could dominate. The critique’s main additive move is the ‘dark forest’ escalation claim (mere possibility of threats deters expansion / induces preemptive violence), but it is asserted rather than argued, relies on strong assumptions (e.g., “infinite negative utility,” offense strongly dominating defense), and doesn’t engage the position’s own uncertainty and conditional structure. So it modestly weakens rather than refutes. It is mostly clear, focused on one issue, and has little filler; but some key claims are overstated or under-justified, reducing correctness and strength.
title: Divergent values imply Hobbesian conflict, not cooperative trade
